Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male cult follower wearing festival wreath headdress in 'grotesque' style. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational between the 3rd to the 2nd century BC and possibly later. Similar to a number of examples from the same or related mould series known from Naukratis (Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge NA535, NA537, NA538, NA539; NA540; Fitzwilliam GR.36.1887; Ashmolean AN1896-1908-E.4758; British Museum GR1886, 0401.1426; Bailey 2008, 66, no.3188, dated to the 2nd century BC). Ptolemaic parallels, probably from Alexandria (Louvre, Besques 1992, D/E 4572 Pl.87g) and favissa at Ras el-Soda, Alexandria, perhaps third to second century BC (Adriani 1952, pls 17, no. 2 and 19, no. 2, left). Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940- 1950), Alexandria. Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche- Orient. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.553) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4611 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
